Info.Label: Expermental Feature
Info.Description: Generates a height map from the input image. A height map is a grayscale representation where pixel brightness corresponds to the terrain height at each point. Commonly used in 3D modeling and game development, it helps create intricate terrain and surface details.

Properties.Name: Gamma Correction
Properties.Summary: Adjusts the gamma correction applied to the height map. Modifying gamma enhances height differences in darker areas or softens them in brighter areas.

Properties.Name: Gain
Properties.Summary: Controls the overall intensity of the height map effect. Higher values emphasize height differences, while lower values reduce them.

Properties.Name: Contrast
Properties.Summary: Enhances or reduces the distinction between light and dark areas. Higher values make height differences more pronounced, while lower values soften them.

Properties.Name: Bias
Properties.Summary: Adjusts the balance between light and dark regions. Increasing bias brightens the image, highlighting higher terrain, while decreasing it darkens the image, emphasizing lower terrain.

Properties.Name: Frequency Weights
Properties.Summary: Seven sliders control the influence of different frequency levels. Weight 1 affects the lowest frequency (largest features), while weight 7 controls the highest frequency (smallest features). Adjusting these sliders fine-tunes the balance between large-scale and fine-scale details.

Properties.Name: Frequency Contrasts
Properties.Summary: These seven sliders adjust contrast at each frequency level. Increasing a slider enhances height differences at that frequency, making the terrain more rugged, while decreasing it smoothens the terrain.
